Award.AwardTitle: Recombination and the Dynamics of Adaptation in Experimental Saccharomyces Cerevisiae (yeast) Populations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The vast majority of species, from viruses to complex multicellular organisms, engage in some form of exchange of genetic material between individuals as a component of reproduction. Biologists have long tried to explain why this form of reproduction is so widespread across nature despite substantial costs. One possibility is that mixing up genomes through recombination allows natural selection to act more efficiently. Yet, asexual reproduction should be more efficient: it avoids the costs of finding partners and mating, and allows individuals to pass all (rather than half) of their genetic material to their offspring. This research will test this hypothesis by comparing adaptation in sexual versus asexual yeast populations. In addition to these scientific goals, this work will involve the development and dissemination of curriculum integrating mathematics and biology education.

Much recent theoretical attention has focused on the potential for recombination to speed adaptation by bringing together beneficial mutations that occur in different genetic backgrounds, alleviating competition and interference between them. Similarly, recombination can purge deleterious mutations from advantageous genetic backgrounds. However, experimental evidence for these effects is scarce. A few laboratory microbial evolution experiments have shown that recombination can indeed increase the rate of mean fitness increase in adapting populations, but until recently it has been impossible to directly observe the effects of recombination at the genotypic level. This research will quantify how recombination alters the sequence-level dynamics of adaptation in experimental populations of budding yeast, by combining a novel genetic system with high-throughput sequencing methods to characterize how recombination alters the dynamics and outcomes of genomic sequence evolution in laboratory budding yeast populations. This work will then track the long-term fate of sexual reproduction in direct competition with asexuals, to determine how and why sexual reproduction is favored or lost in adapting populations. This project will produce extensive data describing the rate, predictability, and genetic basis of adaptation in laboratory populations that will contribute to the advancement of the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recombination is pervasive throughout nature, despite its inherent costs. Understanding the evolutionary forces responsible for this phenomenon is a longstanding challenge in evolutionary biology. That is, why are sexual reproduction and recombination so widespread, when it would be simpler and more efficient for organisms to reproduce clonally? Evolutionary theory has provided a number of potential explanations. Much recent attention has focused on one possibility: recombination can alleviate interference selection. The basic idea is that in the absence of genetic exchange, natural selection often faces a problem: there is too much going on at once. Particularly in large microbial and viral populations, many mutations are often present simultaneously. If natural selection could act on each mutation independently, it could keep the beneficial mutations while purging the deleterious. However, in the absence of recombination, a mutation cannot increase or decrease in frequency without all the other mutations in that particular chromosome doing the same; these mutations are physically linked. In this scenario, recombination can be favored because it can bring together beneficial mutatinos that occur in different genetic backgrounds (and separate beneficial mutations from deleterious “baggage”), making natural selection more efficient and potentially speeding adaptation.

 

While this explanation is theoretically appealing, experimental evidence for these effects has been limited. While a few experimental studies have shown that recombination can indeed increase the rate of fitness increase in adapting populations, until recently it has been impossible to directly observe how recombination acts to produce this outcome at the genotypic level. The overall objective of this project was to fill this gap by quantifying how recombination affects the dynamics of adaptation at the genotypic level, using experimental evolution in budding yeast as a model system.

 

Our experimental work relied on a novel genetic system we developed to precisely control recombination rates in budding yeast. Using this system, we evolved laboratory populations at a variety of different recombination rates, and used high-throughput whole-genome sequencing to observe how recombination affected the dynamics of individual mutations that arose and spread through these populations. By tracking the evolutionary fates of each mutation, and combining this with analysis of how the fitness of each population changed over time, we characterized how recombination affects evolutionary dynamics. We also developed novel “DNA barcoding” methods that allowed us to track the fates of individual rare lineages within evolving populations, and to analyze tradeoffs that occur as populations adapt. We combined this experimental work with theory aimed at analyzing the dynamics of individual mutations in rapidly evolving microbial populations, which provides a framework for analyzing how interference between mutations affects evolution. Our project also generated large data sets describing mutational dynamics, sequence diversity, and fitness in evolving laboratory yeast populations, along with the corresponding yeast strains. Finally, the PI developed and taught a novel curriculum for introductory undergraduate biology, which provides an integrated introduction to biology, physics, chemistry, computer science, and mathematics, and co-organized a summer workshop which allowed a broader community of physical scientists to gain training to help them transition into evolution and population genetics.
